array.string: Napoleon marries Marie-Louise of Austria.
In addition to the desire for an heir, Napoleon sought the validation and legitimization of his Empire by marrying a member of one of the leading royal families of Europe.
Napoleon officially makes Holland part of his empire.
Napoleon abolishes the kingdom of Holland and incorporates the region under direct rule within his French empire.
Napoleon invades Russia.

Napoleon's Grande Armée crossed the Neman River in an attempt to engage and defeat the Russian Army. Napoleon hoped to compel the Emperor of All Russia, Alexander I, to cease trading with British merchants.
Napoleon defeats the Russian army of Alexander I near the village of Borodino.

The armies of the Russian and French empires clashed in one of the climactic battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The survival of the Russian army after Borodino was a key factor in Napoleon's eventual defeat.
Napoleon occupies Moscow.

Napoleon Bonaparte’s Grande Armée enters the city of Moscow, only to find the population evacuated. The deserted city held no czarist officials to sue for peace and no great stores of food or supplies to reward the French soldiers for their long march.
Napoleon's Grand Army crosses Berezina River in retreat from Russia.

Under attack from the Russians, the army escaped destruction thanks to the sacrifice of the pontonniers of general Eblé who constructed two bridges which allowed the major part of the army to cross the river.
French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte defeated a much larger Austrian, Prussian and Russian force.
Napoleon defeats the Austrians, Russians and Prussians at the Battle of Dresden
The Battle of Leipzig concludes, giving Napoleon Bonaparte one of his worst defeats.

Decisively defeated again, Napoleon was compelled to return to France while the Sixth Coalition kept up its momentum, dissolving the Confederation of the Rhine and invading France early the next year.
European forces march into Paris after defeating Napoleon.
European forces allied against Napoleonic France march triumphantly into Paris, formally ending a decade of French domination on the Continent.
Napoleon abdicates for the first time.
Napoleon's broken forces gave up and Napoleon offered to step down in favor of his son. When this offer was rejected, he abdicated
